natural problem: Apartment rentals in Fairview run $\$$0.90 per square foot. Jillian has determined that she can afford $\$$630 per month for rent. What is the largest apartment, in square feet, she should consider at the given rate?
natural solution: Let the size of the apartment be $s$. The cost will be $0.9s$. The maximum comes when this is $630$, so $$630=0.9s\Rightarrow s=\boxed{700}$$ square feet.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rent_per_sqft total_rent :: real
assumes h0 : "rent_per_sqft = 0.90"
and h1 : "total_rent = 630"
shows  "total_rent / rent_per_sqft = 700"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Apartment rentals in Fairview run $\$$0.90 per square foot. Jillian has determined that she can afford $\$$630 per month for rent. What is the largest apartment, in square feet, she should consider at the given rate? The final Answer is 700
 ### Proof
 Let the size of the apartment be $s$. The cost will be $0.9s$. The maximum comes when this is $630$, so $$630=0.9s\Rightarrow s=\boxed{700}$$ square feet.
 *)

theorem
fixes rent_per_sqft total_rent :: real
assumes h0 : "rent_per_sqft = 0.90"
and h1 : "total_rent = 630"
shows  "total_rent / rent_per_sqft = 700"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If the rent per square foot is $0.90 and the total rent is $630, how many square feet does the rented space have? The final answer is 700 square feet.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cost_per_sqft :: real and budget :: real and area :: real
assumes h0 : "cost_per_sqft = 0.90"
and h1 : "budget = 630"
and h2 : "cost_per_sqft * area = budget"
shows  "area = 700"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Apartment rentals in Fairview run $\$$0.90 per square foot. Jillian has determined that she can afford $\$$630 per month for rent. What is the largest apartment, in square feet, she should consider at the given rate? The final Answer is 700
 ### Proof
 Let the size of the apartment be $s$. The cost will be $0.9s$. The maximum comes when this is $630$, so $$630=0.9s\Rightarrow s=\boxed{700}$$ square feet.
 *)

theorem
fixes cost_per_sqft :: real and budget :: real and area :: real
assumes h0 : "cost_per_sqft = 0.90"
and h1 : "budget = 630"
and h2 : "cost_per_sqft * area = budget"
shows  "area = 700"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If the cost per square foot to build a house is $0.90 and the budget is $630, what is the total area that can be built within the budget? The final answer is 700 square feet.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rent_per_sqft rent_budget :: real
and total_sqft :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "rent_per_sqft = 0.90"
and h1 : "rent_budget = 630"
and h2 : "\<forall> sqft. total_sqft sqft = rent_per_sqft * sqft"
shows  "total_sqft (rent_budget / rent_per_sqft) = 700"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Apartment rentals in Fairview run $\$$0.90 per square foot. Jillian has determined that she can afford $\$$630 per month for rent. What is the largest apartment, in square feet, she should consider at the given rate? The final Answer is 700
 ### Proof
 Let the size of the apartment be $s$. The cost will be $0.9s$. The maximum comes when this is $630$, so $$630=0.9s\Rightarrow s=\boxed{700}$$ square feet.
 *)

theorem
fixes rent_per_sqft rent_budget :: real
and total_sqft :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "rent_per_sqft = 0.90"
and h1 : "rent_budget = 630"
and h2 : "\<forall> sqft. total_sqft sqft = rent_per_sqft * sqft"
shows  "total_sqft (rent_budget / rent_per_sqft) = 700"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If the rent per square foot is $0.90 and your total budget for rent is $630, how many square feet can you afford to rent? The final answer is 700 square feet.

a_4.formal problem:

fixes rent_per_sqft :: real and jillian_budget :: real and apartment_size :: real
assumes h0 : "rent_per_sqft = 0.90"
and h1 : "jillian_budget = 630"
shows  "apartment_size = jillian_budget / rent_per_sqft"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Apartment rentals in Fairview run $\$$0.90 per square foot. Jillian has determined that she can afford $\$$630 per month for rent. What is the largest apartment, in square feet, she should consider at the given rate? The final Answer is 700
 ### Proof

 *)

theorem
fixes rent_per_sqft :: real and jillian_budget :: real and apartment_size :: real

and h1 : "jillian_budget = 630"
shows  "apartment_size = jillian_budget / rent_per_sqft"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Jillian has a budget of $630 to rent an apartment. If the rent is $0.90 per square foot, how many square feet can she afford to rent? The answer is the budget divided by the rent per square foot.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rent_per_sqft rent_budget apartment_size :: real
assumes h0 : "rent_per_sqft = 0.90"
and h1 : "rent_budget = 630"
and h2 : "rent_per_sqft * apartment_size \<le> rent_budget"
shows  "apartment_size \<ge> 700"
